title: Independent sets in association schemes
summary:
Let $X$ be $k$-regular graph on $v$ vertices and let $\tau$ denote the least
eigenvalue of its adjacency matrix $A(X)$. If $\alpha(X)$ denotes the maximum
size of an independent set in $X$, we have the following well known bound: \[
\alpha(X) \le\frac{v}{1-\frac{k}{\tau}}. \] It is less well known that if
equality holds here and $S$ is a maximum independent set in $X$ with
characteristic vector $x$, then the vector \[ x-\frac{|S|}{v}\one \] is an
eigenvector for $A(X)$ with eigenvalue $\tau$. In this paper we show how this
can be used to characterise the maximal independent sets in certain classes of
graphs. As a corollary we show that a graph defined on the partitions of
$\{1,...,9\}$ with three cells of size three is a core.

Introduction

Let P(33 ) be the graph whose vertices are the partitions of {1, . . . , 9} with
three cells of size three, where two such partitions are adjacent if each triple
in one partition contains one point from each triple of the other. (We will say
that two such partitions are skew.) Elementary arguments yield that P(33 )
is a regular graph with valency 36 and with 280 vertices.
In [11], Meagher and Stevens ask whether this graph is a core; this calls
for some definitions. If X and Y are graphs, a map f from V (X) to V (Y ) is a
homomorphism if, whenever u and v are adjacent vertices in X, their images
f (x) and f (y) are adjacent in Y . An endomorphism of X is a homomorphism
from X to itself. Any automorphism of X is an endomorphism and we
say that X is a core if all endomorphisms of X are automorphisms. For
background on these topics, see [7, Chapter 6].
In this paper we prove that P(33 ) is a core. The central part of our
argument is a determination of the independent sets of maximal size. The
method we use has other applications; we present two of these.

6

The Characterisation

We prove that an independent set of size 70 in P(33 ) must be one of the sets
Si,j .
Let S be some independent set of size 70 in P(33 ), and z its characteristic
vector. By Theorem 3.1 we know that z − 14 1 lies in the eigenspace of X with
eigenvalue −12 and, from Corollary 4.2, it follows that z lies in the column
space of M. From Lemma 5.1 we see that S must contain two vertices a and
b whose meet has exactly seven cells-two pairs and five singletons.
We have za = zb = 1 and zt = 0 for all vertices t that are adjacent to a
or b. Let M1 be the submatrix of M composed of the rows corresponding to
the vertices adjacent to a or b. There is a vector h such that z = Mh, and
we then have M1 h = 0. Let N be a matrix whose columns are a basis for
the null space of M1 , so h lies in the column space of N and z lies in the
7

 column space of MN. Let C be the matrix formed by the non-zero columns
of the reduced column-echelon form of MN. Then there is a vector y such
that z = Cy. Since C is in reduced column form and has full column rank, it
has a set of rows that form an identity matrix of order rk(C) × rk(C). Since
z is a 01-vector, this implies that y is a 01-vector.
We now actually compute C using Maple, and find that its rank is six.
Therefore y is one of 26 01-vectors and, using Maple again, we find that only
three of these choices for y have the property that Cy is a 01-vector: one of
these is the zero vector, and the other two are the characteristic vectors of
the two Sij that contain a and b.
The second Maple computation can be somewhat elided, as we now describe. It suffices to identify a submatrix C0 corresponding to a subset of
the rows of C such that whenever y and C0 y are 01-vectors then Cy is the
characteristic vector of one of the two Sij that contain a and b, or the zero
vector. We made no serious attempt to find an "optimal" C0 , but a casual
glance at C reveals examples with m = 3.

A Core

We show that, if the sets Si,j are the only maximum independent sets in
P(33 ), then P(33 ) is a core.

7.1 Lemma. L(K2m+1 ) is a core.
Proof. Let Y be the core of L(K2m+1 ). Then Y is vertex- and arc-transitive,
and ω(Y ) = 2m. Since Y is an induced subgraph of X, it is a line graph and
therefore it is the line graph of an edge-transitive graph W with at least one
vertex of valency 2m. If W is not bipartite, it is vertex-transitive and hence
regular; therefore W = K2m+1 . If W is bipartite it is semi-regular. If W has
two vertices of degree 2m they must be adjacent and therefore, since W is
edge-transitive, each edge joins two vertices of degree 2m and W = K2m+1 .
The only remaining case is when W has a unique vertex of degree 2m, whence
W = K1,2m and Y = K2m . But |V (Y )| divides |L(K2m+1 )|. Since 2m does
not divide m(2m + 1), we conclude that L(K2m+1 ) is its own core.
We note that the edge set of L(K2m ) can be partitioned into 2m − 1
perfect matchings. It follows that the core of L(K2m ) is K2m−1 .

Let α be a block of the Witt design and suppose x, y are two points not
in α. There are five blocks that contain x and y and, since any two distinct
blocks have at most two points in common, these five blocks partition the 20
points other than x and y. It follows that three of these five blocks meet α in
two points, and the remaining pair of blocks are disjoint from α. Hence the
blocks disjoint from α form a 2-design on 16 points with block size six and
with λ = 2. From this we deduce that there are exactly 16 blocks disjoint
from α and so N is the incidence matrix of a symmetric design.
Therefore N is invertible and so it follows that supp(h) ⊆ α. Therefore
each block in supp(x) contains supp(h), and consequently these 21 blocks
have a point in common.
Since the Witt graph is the graph induced by the vertices not adjacent to
a given vertex in the Higman-Sims graph, our result leads to a determination
of all independent sets of size 22 in the Higman-Sims graph. It is well known
that the maximal independent sets of the Witt graph are as shown above:
see for example [4], where the maximal independent sets in the Higman-Sims
graph are determined by computer. However our proof is new and gives
further evidence that our method has a wide range of application.
